conversation.content: [hesitantly] The vacuum's in the west wing, third door on the left, though I suppose you'll need help finding it since the hallways all look rather similar these days.
[professionally] I've got the work order here for a 1952 Hoover Constellation, says it needs a motor rebuild and new seals. [pause] This place is bigger than I expected from the address.
[quietly] Yes, well, it used to house quite a large family once upon a time. [clearing throat] Now it's just me rattling around in all these empty rooms, trying to keep things running.
Funny thing about old vacuums, they outlast their owners sometimes, keep working long after everything else falls apart around them.
[shaky voice] That particular vacuum belonged to your mother actually. [long pause] She insisted on doing the cleaning herself even after we could afford staff.
[confused] My mother? [very quietly] How would you know anything about my mother, she never mentioned living anywhere like this.
[regretful] Because I'm your father, Daniel. [sighs] The one who left when you were seven and never came back.
[angry] You're lying, my father died years ago, that's what Mom told us. [frustrated] Some old man in a crumbling house doesn't get to claim he's my dead father. [exhales]
[very sincerely] The scar on your left palm from when you tried to fix my pocket watch and the spring cut you. [pause] You were always taking things apart to see how they worked.
[shaky voice] That doesn't prove anything, lots of kids have scars, lots of kids liked fixing things. [quieter] Why would you leave us and then call me here thirty years later?
[exhausted] I didn't call you here on purpose, I just needed the vacuum fixed and yours was the only shop still servicing vintage models. [sighs] Perhaps fate has a sense of irony.
[bitter] Fate? You think fate brought me to this decaying monument to your selfishness? [loudly] We lived in a two-bedroom apartment while you sat in your manor! [coughs]
[very quietly] I know.
[whisperning] Just tell me why.
[slowly] Your grandfather threatened to disinherit everything if I married beneath the family name. [pause] I was young and weak and chose money over love, over you.
[empathetically] Mom never said anything bad about you, even when we couldn't afford groceries some weeks. [sniffles] She just said you had your reasons and we should focus on moving forward.
[warm] She was always kinder than I deserved, your mother. [very quietly] I've regretted my choice every single day since, watching this place rot around me like my conscience. [sighs]
[forgiving] The vacuum's motor is shot but I can rebuild it with parts from my shop. [gently] It'll take a few visits to get it running properly again, if that's alright with you.
[relieved] I'd like that very much, Daniel. [warmly] Perhaps we could have tea while you work, and you could tell me about your life, about who you became. [pause]
Tea sounds good, and maybe you could tell me about her, about the parts of her life I never knew, before she met you and after you left.
